title: Course Overview
body: Watch the trailer for the "Limits to Growth - Sustainability and the Circular Economy" course and get a first idea of what this course is about, what topics we will cover and how you can sign-up.
pageBody:
Watch our course trailer and get an idea of what this course is about, what topics we will cover and how you can sign-up. 

The Clausthal University of Technology offers a free online course titled „The Limits to Growth – Sustainability and the Circular Economy “. This course will introduce you to the circular economy, sustainability, and related concepts (biocapacity, etc.). You will learn about sustainability goals and different approaches to sustainability and gain an understanding of the basics of climate change, environmental pollution, and dwindling non-renewable resources.

title: Introduction
body: Technology holds immense potential to drive sustainability and can offer innovative solutions like renewable energy, efficient waste management, and smart resource utilisation. At the same time, relying on technology is insufficient, as it overlooks the importance of human behaviour, ethical considerations, and systemic changes.
subtitle: L07 - Technologies and Sustainability
pageBody: Technology holds immense potential to drive sustainability and can offer innovative solutions like renewable energy, efficient waste management, and smart resource utilisation. However, realising these possibilities requires overcoming challenges like e-waste management energy consumption in tech production. At the same time, relying on technology is insufficient, as it overlooks the importance of human behaviour, ethical considerations, and systemic changes.

title: L00 - Organization
body: Here you can find the live lecture recording explaining how the course is organised and the lecture slides of the current semester.
subtitle: Lecture Recording and Slides
pageBody: Here you can find the live lecture recording explaining how the course is organised and the lecture slides of the current semester.

title: Lecture L03
body: Climate change stands as one of the most pressing issues of our time, affecting ecosystems, economies, and societies worldwide. In this chapter, we will explore the science, impacts, and causes of climate change, emphasizing its profound implications for sustainability.
pageBody:
Climate change stands as one of the most pressing issues of our time, affecting ecosystems, economies, and societies worldwide. In this chapter, we will explore the science, impacts, and causes of climate change, emphasizing its profound implications for sustainability. As we delve into the complexities of this global challenge, we'll also examine strategies, policies, and individual actions aimed at mitigating its effects and building a resilient, sustainable future

Below, you can find the lecture recording, the slides for this lecture and the exercise for this lecture. Lecture recordings will be available a day after the live sessions. By clicking on the links, you will be redirected to the video server of the TU Clausthal and our publicly available teaching material on GitHub.

title: Lecture L02
body: Our planet faces an alarming convergence of environmental degradation, resource depletion, and escalating social and political tensions. In this session, we will explore how pollution and resource scarcity amplify these challenges and social disparities.
pageBody:
Our planet faces an alarming convergence of environmental degradation, resource depletion, and escalating social and political tensions. In this session, we will unravel the intricate connections between these challenges, exploring how environmental pollution amplify social disparities and spark political instability.

Below, you can find the lecture recording, the slides for this lecture and the exercise for this lecture. Lecture recordings will be available a day after the live sessions. By clicking on the links, you will be redirected to the video server of the TU Clausthal and our publicly available teaching material on GitHub.

title: Linear Economy
body: Before we can understand circular economic models, we have to take a look at the traditional, linear model of production and consumption, where resources are extracted, used to create products, and then discarded as waste. It follows a "take, make, dispose" approach.
subtitle: L08 - Circular Economy
pageBody: A linear economy is a traditional model of production and consumption where resources are extracted, used to create products, and then discarded as waste. It follows a "take, make, dispose" approach, leading to resource depletion and environmental impact. In contrast to a circular economy, which promotes sustainability by emphasizing recycling and reusing materials, a linear economy lacks a closed-loop system.

title: Circular Societies
body: Beyond the circular economy, we delve into the idea of creating societies that embrace circular principles. This entails fostering inclusivity, sharing resources, reducing inequalities, and promoting cooperation.
subtitle: L08 - Circular Societies
pageBody: Beyond the circular economy, we delve into the idea of creating societies that embrace circular principles. This entails fostering inclusivity, sharing resources, reducing inequalities, and promoting cooperation. We'll explore how circular thinking can reshape governance, education, and community dynamics, ultimately envisioning a world where human well-being and environmental health coexist harmoniously.

title: Political (In) Action
body: This lecture will discuss different understandings and definitions of sustainable development. Additionally, we will examine the dynamic interplay between political and social actors in addressing and delaying actions to fight urgent global challenges.
subtitle: L04 - A History of Political (In) Action
pageBody: This lecture will discuss different understandings and definitions of sustainable development. Additionally, we will examine the dynamic interplay between political and social actors in addressing and delaying actions to fight urgent global challenges.

title: Life Cycle Assessement - Part 1
body: Life cycle assessments (LCAs) are powerful tools for evaluating the environmental impacts of products, processes, and services throughout their entire life cycle. In this session, we will explore the methodology, principles, and applications of LCAs in sustainability efforts.
subtitle: L06 - Life Cycle Assessement
pageBody: Life cycle assessments (LCAs) are powerful tools for evaluating the environmental impacts of products, processes, and services throughout their entire life cycle. In this session, we will explore the methodology, principles, and applications of LCAs in sustainability efforts. From raw material extraction to disposal, LCAs provide insights into resource use, emissions, and energy consumption, aiding in informed decision-making for a more sustainable future.

title: Lecture L10
body:
While the circular economy is a critical step, we'll now venture into advanced strategies that push the boundaries of sustainability.

Part 1
pageBody:
The lecture will be held live on 15.01.2025 at 1:15 - 2:45 p.m. via the BBB virtual classroom platform (Link).

Below, you can find the lecture recording, the slides for this lecture, and the exercise for this lecture. Lecture recordings will be available a day after the live sessions.

title: Sustainable Everyday Practices
body: Throughout this module, we will delve into examples of sustainable everyday practices, discuss why it is crucial to embrace sustainable practices in your everyday life and explore the differences between individual and corporate sustainability.
pageBody:
Throughout this module, we will delve into various examples of sustainable everyday practices. By exploring these examples, you will gain a comprehensive understanding of how small actions in your daily life can contribute to a more sustainable world. Moreover, we will discuss the reasons why it is crucial to embrace sustainable practices in your everyday life. Furthermore, we will explore the differences between individual and corporate sustainability. While individuals have the power to make choices and take actions in their personal lives, corporations have a larger scale and influence in driving sustainable change.

By the end of this module, you will have a comprehensive overview of sustainable everyday practices, (hopefully) be inspired by examples of how you can make a difference, understand the reasons to act more sustainably in your everyday life, and recognize the distinct roles and respobsibilities of individuals and corporations in promoting sustainability.

title: Introduction
body: In this lecture, we will explore the concepts of ecological limits and planetary boundaries. As our planet faces escalating environmental challenges, it is essential to grasp the constraints within which our societies must operate to ensure future worth living.
subtitle: L05 - Planetary Boundaries and the Limits to Growth
pageBody: In this lecture, we will explore the concepts of ecological limits and planetary boundaries. As our planet faces escalating environmental challenges, it is essential to grasp the constraints within which our societies must operate to ensure future worth living.

title: Course Guide
body: This course guide will give you an overview of the learning goals, structure and organisation of the course and the different types of learning material and techniques you will encounter during the course.
subtitle: Course Organization and FAQs
pageBody:
Welcome to the online course "The Limits to Growth – Sustainability and the Circular Economy". The ETCE Lab is teaching this course at the Technical University of Clausthal. 

This course guide will give you an overview of the learning goals, structure and organisation of the course and the different types of learning material and techniques you will encounter during the course.

title: Massive Open Online Course (MOOC)
body: Find out what a MOOC is and how we will use asynchronous learning, pre-recorded videos and interactive content in this course.
subtitle: A Look Behind the Scenes
pageBody:
The ETCE Lab at Clausthal University of Technology has been creating MOOC content for the course "Limits to Growth – Sustainability and the Circular Economy" since March 2023. We are still working on expanding and improving the course and are thankful for your feedback. 

In this chapter, we will give you further insights into what exactly a Massive Open Online Course is and how we produce the interactive and asynchronous content for this course.

title: Alternative Sources of Energy
body: Alternative energy sources encompass various options, including solar power, wind energy, hydropower, geothermal energy, and bioenergy. Each alternative offers a more sustainable and environmentally friendly opportunity than traditional fossil fuels. In this section, we will discuss different technologies and their advantages and disadvantages.
subtitle: L07 - Technologies and Sustainability
pageBody: Alternative energy sources encompass various options, including solar power, wind energy, hydropower, geothermal energy, orbioenergy. Each alternative offers a more sustainable and environmentally friendly opportunity than traditional fossil fuels. In this section, we will discuss different technologies and their advantages and disadvantages.

title: Circular Economy
body: A circular economy is an alternative economic model designed to minimize waste and make the most of resources. It focuses on recycling, reusing, and regenerating materials to create a closed-loop system that promotes sustainability.
subtitle: L08 - Circular Economy
pageBody: A circular economy is an alternative economic model designed to minimize waste and make the most of resources. It focuses on recycling, reusing, and regenerating materials to create a closed-loop system that promotes sustainability and reduces environmental impact.

title: Food Waste and Foodsharing
body: In the following section, you will learn more about one specific sustainable practice: foodsharing. What exactly is foodsharing, how does it work and how can you share food with others or get food that others are willing to share.
pageBody:
Food waste has become a global predicament of alarming proportions, capturing the attention of individuals, organizations, and policymakers worldwide. Each year, a staggering amount of food is needlessly discarded, exacerbating issues of hunger, environmental degradation, and economic inefficiency. This growing crisis demands immediate attention and concerted efforts from all sectors of society to tackle the multifaceted challenges it presents.

Throughout this segment, we will take a closer look at the scale at which food is being wasted worldwide on a daily basis. We will scrutinize some of the underlying reasons as to why is food being needlessly thrown away and talk about the the far-reaching economic, environmental and social implications of food waste. Moreover, it is also important to take a look possible solutions both on the political level as well as on an individual level. By looking at foodsharing as a local and self-organized practice, we want to point out a practical pathway to saving food and living more sustainably.

title: World3 Model
body: To further understand the ideas of planetary boundaries and an ecosystem with limits to growth, we will look at the World3 model and the different scenarios it describes.
subtitle: L05 - Planetary Boundaries and the Limits to Growth

title: The Importance of Individual Action
body: Addressing climate change requires collective efforts on individual, community, national, and global levels. In the lecture, we discussed the international and national perspectives. For the exercise, we want to look at what can be done on the community and individual levels!
pageBody: Addressing climate change requires collective efforts on individual, community, national, and global levels. In the lecture, we have discussed the global and national perspective. For the exercise we want to take a closer look at what can be done on the community and individual level!

title: Carbon Capture and Storage
body: Carbon capture and storage (CCS) is a technology designed to mitigate the impact of carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from industrial processes and power generation. It involves capturing CO2 emissions at their source, such as from power plants or industrial facilities, before they are released into the atmosphere.
subtitle: L07 - Technologies and Sustainability
pageBody:
Carbon capture and storage (CCS) is a technology designed to mitigate the impact of carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from industrial processes and power generation. It involves capturing CO2 emissions at their source, such as from power plants or industrial facilities, before they are released into the atmosphere. 

CCS aims to prevent large amounts of CO2, a greenhouse gas contributing to climate change, from entering the atmosphere. While it's considered a potential tool for reducing emissions, it also faces challenges such as high costs, potential environmental risks associated with long-term storage, and the need for significant infrastructure development.

title: Performance Economy
body: A performance economy is centered on the idea of providing services and performance outcomes to customers rather than selling products. In this model, businesses retain ownership of products, ensuring their optimal performance and longevity, while customers pay for the utility or service derived from the product.
subtitle: L08 - Circular Economy
pageBody: A performance economy is centered on the idea of providing services and performance outcomes to customers rather than selling products. In this model, businesses retain ownership of products, ensuring their optimal performance and longevity, while customers pay for the utility or service derived from the product.

title: Resilient Food Production
body: Climate-resilient food production refers to agricultural practices and systems designed to withstand and adapt to the challenges posed by climate change. It is crucial for ensuring food security in the face of a changing climate and to adapt and mitigate the impacts of climate change on agriculture.
subtitle: L07 - Technologies and Sustainability

displayTitle: A Short History of Political (In-) Action
body: This lecture will discuss different understandings and definitions of sustainable development. Additionally, we will examine the dynamic interplay between political and social actors in addressing and delaying actions to fight urgent global challenges.

title: Limits to Growth and Planetary Boundaries
displayTitle: Limits to Growth and Planetary Boundaries
body: In this lecture, we will explore the concepts of ecological limits and planetary boundaries. As our planet faces escalating environmental challenges, it is essential to grasp the constraints within which our societies must operate to ensure a future worth living.
pageBody: In this chapter, we will explore the critical concepts of ecological limits and planetary boundaries that shape our understanding of sustainable development. As our planet faces escalating environmental challenges, we must grasp the constraints within which our societies must operate to ensure a viable future.

title: Life Cycle Assessement
body: Life cycle assessments (LCAs) are powerful tools for evaluating the environmental impacts of products, processes, and services throughout their entire life cycle. In this session, we will explore the methodology, principles, and applications of LCAs in sustainability efforts.
pageBody: Life cycle assessments (LCAs) are powerful tools for evaluating the environmental impacts of products, processes, and services throughout their entire life cycle. In this session, we will explore the methodology, principles, and applications of LCAs in sustainability efforts. From raw material extraction to disposal, LCAs provide insights into resource use, emissions, and energy consumption, aiding in informed decision-making for a more sustainable future.

title: Ethics and Morals of Sustainability
body: Sustainable innovations can potentially drive positive change, from renewable energy to efficient transportation. Yet, it's essential to acknowledge their limitations. In this chapter, we will scrutinise the boundaries of technology, emphasising the need for holistic approaches to achieve genuine sustainability.
pageBody: Sustainable innovations can potentially drive positive change, from renewable energy to efficient transportation. Yet, it's essential to acknowledge their limitations. While technology can mitigate some environmental challenges, it's not a one-size-fits-all solution. We'll scrutinise the boundaries of technology, emphasising the need for holistic approaches that encompass social, economic, and behavioral aspects to achieve genuine sustainability. By understanding the possibilities and constraints, we can chart a more effective course toward a sustainable future.

title: Circular Economy
body: As we confront the challenges of resource depletion and waste accumulation, the concept of a circular economy emerges as a transformative solution. In this lecture, we will delve into the main characteristics of a circular economy, where products and materials are reused, refurbished, remanufactured, and recycled.
pageBody: As we confront the challenges of resource depletion and waste accumulation, the concept of a circular economy emerges as a transformative solution. In this chapter, we will delve into the main characteristics of a circular economy, where products and materials are reused, refurbished, remanufactured, and recycled, reducing waste and environmental impact.

title: Circular Societies
body: Beyond the circular economy, we delve into the idea of creating societies that embrace circular principles. This entails fostering inclusivity, sharing resources, reducing inequalities, and promoting cooperation. We'll explore how circular thinking can reshape governance, education, and community dynamics, ultimately envisioning a world where human well-being and environmental health coexist harmoniously.
pageBody: Beyond the circular economy, we delve into the idea of creating societies that embrace circular principles. This entails fostering inclusivity, sharing resources, reducing inequalities, and promoting cooperation. We'll explore how circular thinking can reshape governance, education, and community dynamics, ultimately envisioning a world where human well-being and environmental health coexist harmoniously.

title: Beyond the Circular Economy I
body: While the circular economy is a critical step, we'll now venture into advanced strategies that push the boundaries of sustainability. Our focus will be on economic models that reimagine consumption, production, and finance. We will explore innovative approaches that prioritize people and the planet over profit, aiming to create a harmonious, prosperous, and sustainable world.
pageBody: While the circular economy is a critical step, we'll now venture into advanced strategies that push the boundaries of sustainability. Our focus will be on economic models that reimagine consumption, production, and finance. We will explore innovative approaches that prioritize people and the planet over profit, aiming to create a harmonious, prosperous, and sustainable world.

title: Invited Lecture
body: For this lecture, we will invite people working on practical solutions towards a more sustainable future to present and discuss their ideas.
pageBody: The lecture will be live on  07.02.2024 at 1:15 - 2:45 p.m. via the BBB virtual classroom platform (Link).

title: Summary
body: In this last lecture, we will take stock of what we have learned about environmental, social, and economic sustainability during the course and what comes next.
pageBody:
In this course, we have explored the nuances of environmental, social, and economic sustainability, recognizing their interplay. Throughout our discussions, we've discovered that sustainable solutions demand collaborative efforts, innovative thinking, and a commitment to change.

The lecture will be live on  05.02.2025 from 1:15 - 2:45 p.m. via the BBB virtual classroom platform (Link).
